In this unit we are exploring measurements of two- and three-dimensional shapes and how these measurements are used to solve real world problems. At the end of this Investigation,

What do you know about measurements of two- and three-dimensional shapes?

At this point students can talk about volume of rectangular prisms being found by knowing how many cubes fit on the bottom layer and multiplying that by the height; volume is Bh or (l • w) • h; surface area is finding the area of all the faces of a rectangular prism and adding all of them together; similar open top rectangular prisms can be created by multiplying all three dimensions by the same scale factor; the surface area of similar open top rectangular prisms can be found by the scale factor squared; the volume of similar open top rectangular prisms can be found by the scale factor cubed.
